page.title: 11The River Stour, Bryanston
page.content: { The Stour}was widened and moved from its course through Bryanston; the old course can be seen near St Martin's. From above the Boathouse to the weir is a km stretch used regularly by the School Boat Club, training in eights, fours & sculls. Canoeists from the School & Blandford also use the river. Bathing used to happen regularly. The river is fished for eels,roach, pike,dace & less common fish - tench, trout,bream & carp. Salmon have again been seen leaping the weir, suggesting the river is now less polluted than it was. Mink are common along the banks. Anglers & boat users conflict on occasion, but the Stour's main problem is the{Blandford Biting Fly,}unique to the area.The fly breeds in the river & delivers a bite which can be painful & temporarily disabling. 1985 was a bad year.Eradication attempts have failed.
